awd_titl_txt: University of Alaska Fairbanks/Sikuliaq Oceanographic Instrumentation
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of Alaska Fairbanks (UAF) operates R/V Sikuliaq, a 261-foot, global class ice-capable oceanographic research vessel owned by the NSF as part of the Academic Research Fleet (ARF) fleet. Sikuliaq provides a general-purpose platform for multidisciplinary research missions from polar to temperate latitudes. The ship was delivered in 2014 and has completed six years of funded operations. UAF requests funds to purchase and install Oceanographic Instrumentation that would be custom engineered to enhance the vessel's capability in support of NSF-sponsored research to be undertaken on Sikuliaq in the future.

In 2021, Sikuliaq completed 233 days, 181 (78%) of which were for NSF. In 2022, the vessel is scheduled to sail 275 days with 217 (79%) days of the schedule for NSF.  With this proposal, UAF provides technical descriptions and rationale for the acquisition of the following Oceanographic Instrumentation.

NSS receiver w/ Iridium augmentation	$18,200
Ice Coring System	$6,980
Stop Gap LAN-LAN Firewall	$20,847
Video encoders for underway displays	$51,580
Compact CTD system for underwire winch	$24,035
						$121,642

Broader Impacts

The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 13-589). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF).  The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
C-Nav X1

 In the spring of 2022, we purchased the C-Nav X1 GNSS receiver bundle from Oceaneering International. The purpose of this upgrade is to leverage DDK Positioning?s advancement in obtaining Precise Point Positioning (PPP) augmentation through the next-generation Iridium satellite network. This is especially important for a vessel like Sikuliaq that regularly operates at high latitudes, and has been impacted by the failing Inmarsat satellites that have historically provided global corrections. The installation was carried out between December 2022 and January 2023. This involved mounting two new antennas atop the main mast, as well as the new receiver and controller/display on the bridge. This positioning system has three main applications - 1) provide position reference input to the vessel?s Dynamic Positioning system, 2) log the NMEA sentences at 1 Hz as a scientific data product, and 3) provide RTCM corrections to the Seapath inertial navigation system in order to achieve centimeter-level accuracy for many of Sikuliaq?s science systems.

 

Ice Corer
 In the spring of 2022, we purchased a Kovacs Mark II coring system that can retrieve 9 cm cores up to 1 meter in length. It came with two 1-meter extension rods to take cores up to 3 meters deep. The ice coring system is available as shared-use sampling equipment to any Sikuliaq user. It can also be loaned out to other vessels if not needed on Sikuliaq. It was used as recently as the Chukchi Sea Primary Production cruise in June and July of 2023. We already have a high-torque cordless right-angle electric drill dedicated to being used with the ice corer when connected to an adapter fitting. We also have a plastic cutting board and saws for sectioning ice cores in the field. Adding the Mark II ice corer to our kit gives Sikuliaq a comprehensive suite of ice sampling equipment for scientific use.

Firewall

 Sikuliaq's FG-101F procurement was placed in September 2022, but there was a minimum 90 day lead time due to supply chain delays. The equipment was received Jan 3 2023, just in time to be configured and deployed on Jan 21, 2023 during Sikuliaq's winter maintenance period in Seattle, Washington. There was approximately 1 hour of network downtime between shutting down the old PaloAlto firewalls and replacing them with the new Foritgate FG-101F devices. The two FG-101F devices are configured in a redundant High-Availability mode with a primary and secondary device. This provides resiliency in the event of a single device failure and also makes it possible to perform system updates with zero network down time. The upgrade went smoothly without any major impacts to production networks and has been stable since Jan 2023.

Compact CTD
 In the spring of 2022, we purchased a FastCAT SBE49 CTD, Power & Data Interface Module (PDIM), and SBE33 deck unit from Seabird Scientific. This gives Sikuliaq the ability to operate a compact CTD and acquire data in realtime through telemetry over a conducting cable. This upgrade pairs nicely with the 800 meters of synthetic EM cable acquired through an SSSE grant for the underwire winch on the ship?s starboard crane. This arrangement primarily benefits light net towing operations such as vertical CalVETs and oblique bongos, to know exactly at what water depth the net is being towed using the FastCAT?s pressure sensor. The underwire winch and FastCAT can also be used as a standalone rapid-cast CTD system if there is no desire to collect water samples. It was used as recently as the NGA-LTER cruise in April and May of 2023, and will be used again on the upcoming DBO-EcoFOCI cruise in September.

 


Last Modified: 07/28/2023
Modified by: Ethan H Roth
